local vs global maximum/minimum



Optimizing functions. Taking the first derivative and setting it equal to 0 gives us either a minimum or maximum. The second derivative allows us to discern between the two.
higher-order derivatives can be used to construct useful approximations (i.e. Taylor’s approximation) to complex functions that are important in understanding the properties of various statistical estimators.

title: Maths - Calculus
text:
Some common rules of derivatives

How to calculate Derivative?

power rule

\(\frac{dx^n}{dx}=nx^{n-1}\)

product rule

\(\frac{d}{dx}f(x)g(x)=f'(x)g(x) +f(x)g'(x)\)

quotient rule

\(\frac{d}{dx}\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}=\frac{f'(x)g(x)-f(x)g'(x)}{(g(x))^2}\)

chain rule

\(\frac{d}{dx}f(g(x))=f'(g(x))g'(x)\)

special rules for logs and exponents

\(\frac{d}{dx}\ln(x)=\frac{1}{x}\)
\(\frac{d}{dx}e^{x}=e^{x}\)





\(\frac{d}{dx}\ln(f(x))=\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)}\)
\(\frac{d}{dx}e^{f(x)}=f'(x)e^{f(x)}\)

title: Maths - Calculus

Constraint optimization

What is constraint optimization?

optimization with constraints
Lagrange multiplier

The idea is to optimize a function subject to some constraints
The problem can be stated as:

maximize \(f(x,y)\) subject to \(g(x,y)=0\)
minimize \(f(x,y)\) subject to \(g(x,y)=0\)

title: Maths - Calculus
text:
Constraint optimization

let us learn some economics
in economics, a consumer faces the problem of maximizing her utility subject to the income constraint:


\[
\max_{x_1,x_2} u(x_1,x_2) \quad s.t. \; p_1x_1 + p_2x_2=y
\]

we can visualize and “solve” the problem using graph

title: Maths - Calculus
text:
Constraint optimization

the optimal solution is at the point where the budget line is tangent to the indifference curve


\[
\frac{MU_1}{MU_2}=\frac{p_1}{p_2}
\]
\(\quad\) where \(MU_1\) and \(MU_2\) are the marginal utilities of good 1 and good 2 respectively

we can solve this problem using the “identity”



\[
u(x_1, x^U_2(x_1))=\bar{u}
\]

we need to solve two equations simultaneously

title: Maths - Calculus
text:
Constraint optimization

the Lagrange multiplier is a method to solve the optimization problem with constraints
the Lagrange function is defined as:


\[
L(x_1,x_2,\lambda)=u(x_1,x_2)+\lambda(y-(p_1x_1+p_2x_2))
\]

the first-order conditions are



\[
\begin{align*}
\frac{\partial u}{\partial x_1} - \lambda p_1 &=0 \\
\frac{\partial u}{\partial x_2} - \lambda p_2 &=0 \\
y-(p_1x_1+p_2x_2) &=0
\end{align*}
\]

title: Maths - Calculus
text:
Constraint optimization

the Lagrange multiplier could be interpreted as the “marginal utility of income” in our example
in economics, the Lagrange multiplier could be interpreted as the “shadow price” of the constraint

e.g. the Lagrange multiplier could be interpreted as the “marginal cost” in production optimization

Reminder: the Lagrange multiplier could be zero, positive or negative
the Lagrange multiplier could be used in very general optimization problems


\[
\max_{x_1, \dots, x_n} f(x_1,\dots, x_n) \quad s.t. \; g_i(x_1,\dots, x_n)=c_i, \quad i=1,\dots,m
\]
